ReviewList.Text: As RandITS has provided a satisfactory synopsis I will not go there. I will say that the character development was excellent. They say half the fun is in getting there and that certainly goes for Breakers. The characters' physical journeys as well as their transitional trips from a bohemian existence to survivalists is accompanied by a constant patter of clever thoughts and dialogue. I stayed up late one night and finished it the next day. Thoroughly enjoyable!

Took me a little while to finish, but what a fantastic story! I kind of felt like I was reading The Stand (my first King novel) or one of Stephen Baxter's excellent books. Great effort that kept me surprised, intrigued and wanting more. I look forward to your next book! Thank you!

I picked this book up as a free Kindle offering. The book reads like two tales in one, it begins as an apocalyptic end-of-the-world story that turns suddenly into an alien invasion plot halfway through. I found the two main characters interesting enough that I didn't get that feeling one sometimes gets with divergent plotlines based on multiple characters, where you lose the flow of the story when the perspective switches from one character to another. The buildup to the two main characters meeting was so drawn out that it was a bit of an anticlimax when they finally joined up. I often found myself thinking, "I wouldn't have done that in that situation," which told me I was getting drawn into the plot. Often the characters themselves would later comment on a foolish decision they had made, in a way that made it believable why they had taken that action at the time. I found Walt's nihilism a bit off-putting at first, though ultimately I ended up rooting for him as the author kept throwing disasters in his path. His transformation into an action hero was a bit jarring, but I thought that the author delivered with an ending that resolved the various threads he'd set up. I also liked how the two main characters were set off each other, one seeking oblivion, the other just trying to keep himself and his wife alive.

I found this book enjoyable. There are some parts that drag on a little too long. But the story is good. The plot was interesting. I have to say it wasn't what I expected. Now, there are some editing errors. Forgotten words here and there. But not enough to ruin the story. I really got to know and feel for the characters. I felt the author did a great job of humanizing them. I'm really hooked on Walt and will most likely pick up the next, just to see what he does! It was great following his journey and seeing him evolve as a person. If you're into Sci-Fi or Post Apocalyptic stories, read this!

ReviewList.Text: I wasn't sure what exactly to expect from this book.  What I didn't expect was to be sucked in from page one.  This was one of those "couldn't put it down" books for me.  I think the author stayed focused on his goals through the entire book, and it showed.  I found the plot to be tight and well-paced.  I appreciated the alternating between Walt and Raymond's points of view as well as the different ways they handled and moved forward with the disaster.  But even with the limited POV, the side characters were always well-developed and meaningful to the story.  Never did an event, action, character, or location feel gratuitous, as if it were thrown in there for no real reason.  Every bit of this book felt intentional and planned, there was obviously a great deal of thought and effort put into the story outside of the actual writing.  I've read other books that fall in a similar plotline to this one and I think this is the finest example of the basic storyline that I've read in a long time.  I'll have no hesitation purchasing and reading other works by this author.

This book was recommended to me by Amazon, as I've read a lot of post-apocalyptic "what if?" thrillers. It started out promising -incurable, indiscriminate virus mismanaged by government bureaucrats - but after a while, all of the different sub-plots started to get tedious. The main character is not particularly likable, which is certainly an interesting way to tell a story, but I found myself feeling no connection at all to him or any of the other characters.

This book was very disappointing and I couldn't finish it . I like details and character development but I don't like page fillers and that's exactly what 80% of this book is, I prefer quality over quantity so this book is definitely not for a person looking for an excellent read.

Breakers is a fantastic book. It opens with a bang and the pace never lets up, right to the end. The author paints a vivid and compelling vision of a dystopian future. Sure, it's bleak - the world is kinda ending - but liberal sprinklings of wicked humor (and artful asides on the modern world) keep things ticking along. There is also a great dose of humanity in this book. Through the eyes of various characters, we see what happens when people get pushed to extremes. To survive, people will do almost anything, but there are unexpected moments of warmth and charity too. A great book, and I'm hoping there will be a follow-up.

I was really wrapped up in this book for maybe the first 1/4 or so.  Maybe it's my fault and I didn't read the entire description of the book prior to buying it, but I bought it thinking it was an apocalyptic book about a pandemic that wiped out the majority of the planet.  The first part of the book did a great job explaining the spread of the virus/whatever and told a great story from two different parts of the country.  I immediately liked it because one part of the story had a couple choosing to "survive" in place, by defending and prepping in a house.  The other part of the story had another guy "surviving" on the move, making his way from the east coast of the USA to the west.  SPOILER ALERT:  Needless to say, the book took a massive downward fall when it is revealed that aliens infected the planet and were now "conquering" the planet.  It gets pretty far-fetched after that revelation.  Had I read that it was an alien-apocalypse I wouldn't have bought it.  If you're into that kind of thing, it's a decent read.  I won't be continuing the series beyond book 1.
